Only one left-hander has ever started a season with a longer streak, and he was named his league\xe2\x80\x99s most valuable player: Willie Hernandez of the 1984 Tigers. Britton cited the Orioles\xe2\x80\x99 late-strike ability, and the bullpen\xe2\x80\x99s success in making those late runs matter, as reasons for the team\xe2\x80\x99s record.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  He also mentioned pitcher Chris Tillman, who has been the only reliable starter on the staff. The Orioles\xe2\x80\x99 rotation has a 5.10 earned run average; through Sunday, its E.R.A. ranked ahead of only Minnesota and Cincinnati, two of the majors\xe2\x80\x99 worst teams. (The Orioles\xe2\x80\x99 bullpen E.R.A. is 3.03.)\xe2\x80\x9cTillman\xe2\x80\x99s really stabilized our rotation, and it\xe2\x80\x99s been a tough thing to ask from him, to really have to be on top of his game every time out,\xe2\x80\x9d Britton said. \xe2\x80\x9cYou think about the pressure he\xe2\x80\x99s got, every time he takes the ball, and he\xe2\x80\x99s done a great job.\xe2\x80\x9dTillman, who starts the series finale on Thursday, is 13-2 with a 3.29 E.R.A. The quality start may be a low standard to meet \xe2\x80\x94 at least six innings, no more than three earned runs \xe2\x80\x94 yet in the 71 games Tillman has not started, the Orioles have managed just 24 quality starts.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  They have made changes. Dylan Bundy, the fourth overall pick in the 2011 draft, made his first career start on Sunday. Vance Worley, a veteran who has been working in long relief, starts Tuesday in place of Ubaldo Jimenez. The Orioles lavished a four-year, $50 million contract on Jimenez \xe2\x80\x94 or $1 million for each of his A.L.-leading 50 walks this season \xe2\x80\x94 that runs through 2017. Now, with a 7.38 E.R.A., he has no clear value to the team. Perhaps Worley can be an answer, but the Orioles badly need to upgrade their rotation before the Aug. 1 nonwaiver deadline.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  The Red Sox did so last week by trading for the All-Star Drew Pomeranz from San Diego, following deals for closer Brad Ziegler from Arizona and infielder Aaron Hill from Milwaukee. The Orioles have been quiet so far, but their players understand the calendar.\xe2\x80\x9cWe think about it,\xe2\x80\x9d Britton said. \xe2\x80\x9cWe can\xe2\x80\x99t control it, obviously, but I think we all know what we need. It\xe2\x80\x99s pretty clear. So you hope that we would make a move to help that out. If we do, it\xe2\x80\x99s great. If we don\xe2\x80\x99t, we\xe2\x80\x99ve got to keep doing what we\xe2\x80\x99re doing.\xe2\x80\x9d  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  If not a starter, Britton said, another reliever could also help the staff. The Orioles have done that before, trading for Miller in their 2014 playoff run. Miller came from the Red Sox for Eduardo Rodriguez, who is now in Boston\xe2\x80\x99s rotation, and helped the Orioles reach the A.L.C.S.They lost four in a row to the Royals, all by one or two runs. The Royals went on to reach Game 7 of that year\xe2\x80\x99s World Series, then won their encore last fall. They, not the Orioles, are thus the model for the back-to-front pitching staff.\xe2\x80\x9cI know the Royals get a lot of credit, and deservedly so, because they won the World Series; we haven\xe2\x80\x99t done that,\xe2\x80\x9d Britton said. \xe2\x80\x9cBut we\xe2\x80\x99ve been building through our bullpen for a long time.\xe2\x80\x9d  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  They have been building that way for five seasons, to be exact, with a lot of wins \xe2\x80\x94 but no pennants \xe2\x80\x94 to validate their style.                     });                 });             }          } })();  The math confronting the Yankees on Monday was simple. They arrived at Yankee Stadium two weeks from the trade deadline, eight and a half games back in the American League East, and hosting first-place Baltimore for four games.If the Yankees were going to get into or out of the playoff race for good, there was no time like the present.\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s where we\xe2\x80\x99re at,\xe2\x80\x9d catcher Brian McCann said after the Yankees took a first step in the right direction with a 2-1 victory over the Orioles. \xe2\x80\x9cA little over two months of baseball left and we\xe2\x80\x99ve got to start winning.\xe2\x80\x9dThe Yankees were buoyed by a confluence of rare events: Ivan Nova escaping trouble at every turn, Alex Rodriguez hitting his first home run in a month, and Aroldis Chapman drawing oohs and aahs, shattering a bat and throwing fastballs that registered at 105 miles per hour. Continue reading the main story        Advertisement  Continue reading the main story      Those events helped prop up an offense that has scored just 10 runs in four games since the All-Star break, and pushed the decisive marker across when Carlos Beltran sharply executed a hit-and-run single in the third inning that sent Brett Gardner to third, from where he scored on a sacrifice fly by McCann on the next at-bat.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Before the game, Manager Joe Girardi did his best to avoid putting too much weight on this series, waving away a question about whether the Yankees needed to sweep it, or at least win three of four to consider themselves contenders.\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m worried about winning tonight,\xe2\x80\x9d Girardi said. \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t ever put numbers on things, because I think it can put limitations on what you do. So we need to win tonight, and then we\xe2\x80\x99ll worry about tomorrow.\xe2\x80\x9dWith the Yankees\xe2\x80\x99 other struggling slugger, Mark Teixeira, out at least until Wednesday after being hit by a pitch on the foot Saturday, Rodriguez drove a 94-m.p.h. fastball from Kevin Gausman deep to left.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Before afternoon showers came and wiped out batting practice, Rodriguez had worked on a drill that the former hitting coach Kevin Long favored. A hitting screen was placed across home plate, bisecting it. Rodriguez then choked up on the bat as balls were tossed to him, refining a technique that would prevent him from getting jammed.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  The work, brief as it was, seemed to have had a desired effect.\xe2\x80\x9cMechanics have been a humongous struggle for me all year,\xe2\x80\x9d Rodriguez said. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s been hard for me to get the ball in the air consistently.\xe2\x80\x9d Sign Up for the Sports Newsletter Get the big sports news, highlights and analysis from Times journalists, with distinctive takes on games and some behind-the-scenes surprises, delivered to your inbox every week. Privacy Policy    He added: \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve been really bad this year. I\xe2\x80\x99ve been working my butt off, and I haven\xe2\x80\x99t been able to figure it out. The last five or six days, working hard with Alan and Marcus, I\xe2\x80\x99m getting to see the light at the end of the tunnel.\xe2\x80\x9d Alan Cockrell and Marcus Thames are the Yankees hitting coaches.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  There was nothing pedestrian about Rodriguez\xe2\x80\x99s home run, his ninth this season, which brought his career total to 696. Rodriguez admired its flight into the bleachers, a worthy way for him to mark the end of a drought that had lasted one month, since he homered against Minnesota\xe2\x80\x99s Ricky Nolasco on June 18.It had also been some time since Rodriguez had celebrated a home run at Yankee Stadium, his last one coming more than three months ago, on April 17, against Seattle\xe2\x80\x99s Hisashi Iwakuma.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Nova, who shut out the Orioles for six innings last month before collapsing in the seventh, had his share of unsteady moments. He escaped the first inning when Pedro Alvarez popped out with the bases loaded. Center fielder Jacoby Ellsbury had to run down two hard-hit balls by Matt Wieters and Ryan Flaherty, and third baseman Chase Headley neatly gloved a smash by Jonathan Schoop.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Yet other than allowing a leadoff homer by Schoop in the third, Nova was unscathed. Once he gained better command of his sinker and curveball, keeping them down, he retired the final seven batters he faced.It was hard to ask for more against the team that leads baseball with 142 home runs, even if the Orioles were without first baseman Chris Davis, who was ill.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  \xe2\x80\x9cThe big thing when you face a club like this is you have to make your pitches, because if you don\xe2\x80\x99t, a lot of them are going to leave the ballpark,\xe2\x80\x9d Girardi said before the game. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd you can\xe2\x80\x99t give them extra outs. You can recover from a solo home run. It\xe2\x80\x99s hard to recover from two and three-run home runs.\xe2\x80\x9dNova, who is 7-5 with a 4.92 E.R.A., did not look like the same pitcher who two weeks ago appeared to be trying to save his spot in the rotation.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  \xe2\x80\x9cHe was wildly effective, a little bit,\xe2\x80\x9d Orioles Manager Buck Showalter said. \xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s got a lot of two-seam movement, he\xe2\x80\x99s one of the top ground-ball throwers in baseball. You look out there at the E.R.A. and stuff \xe2\x80\x94 you wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t think that watching him tonight.\xe2\x80\x9dThe Yankees, like the Orioles, had bountiful opportunities early: Beltran rocketed a double to the right-center gap and Starlin Castro sliced one into the right-field corner, but neither scored.After Schoop\xe2\x80\x99s home run tied the score, McCann brought Gardner sliding home on a fly ball that center fielder Adam Jones caught but skipped too late on the throw. It gave the Yankees a lead and a chance to look forward to the next day.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  \xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s all we can do at this point because of all the noise around,\xe2\x80\x9d Girardi said. \xe2\x80\x9cI think you just have to focus on tomorrow.\xe2\x80\x9d  A version of this article appears in print on July 19, 2016, on Page B9 of the New York edition with the headline: Rodriguez Homers, and Nova Helps Yankees Edge First-Place Orioles. I find myself asking once again, after last night\'s Orioles loss to the Yankees, why do the Orioles hitters hate scoring runs for Kevin Gausman? The answer is surely not that it is some intentional thing because they dislike him, but as they flopped their way through a game started by a Yankees pitcher, Ivan Nova, who was both homer-prone and entered the game with a 5+ ERA, I just had to wonder, what the heck, you know?    If you haven\'t read it yet, make sure to check out\xc2\xa0our recap of the game. And while you\'re at it, here\'s Ryan Flaherty getting caught on the MASN cameras\xc2\xa0saying something you can\'t say on television. This may be the greatest GIF in the history of mankind. Lots to be anxious about in the links today, so sorry in advance - and the links don\'t even get into the fact that top/only pitching prospect Hunter Harvey is headed to pay a visit to Dr. James Andrews. Around the blogO\'sphere Hyun Soo Kim unsure if he can avoid disabled list - School of RochWell, that sounds like bad news.    Wieters has foot X-rayed following 2-1 loss - School of Roch...oh. That\'s also bad news. I\'m going to be mad if a Yankees pitcher again takes out a key Orioles player in a potential playoff season. Alright, let\'s talk about other stuff.    Baltimore Orioles, So Consistent, Crave Another Measure of Success (New York Times)With the Orioles swinging into New York, but not like Spider-Man, although that would be awesome, the paper of record deigns to notice their existence. 2016 Trade Value: #11 to #20 | FanGraphs BaseballFormer ESPNer Bill Simmons introduced the concept of the trade value rankings to the sports blog world. Fangraphs has refined it for baseball players - and in this range of the rankings, an Orioles player finally appears.    Rage against the machines: MLB stars don\'t want to see robot umps | MLB | Sporting NewsThey talked to a bunch of All-Stars in San Diego about robot umpire strike zones - interesting quotes from the two O\'s All-Stars here on their feelings about it. Orioles reportedly had third-highest local TV ratings through All-Star break - Baltimore SunTurns out that people actually watch the Orioles on MASN. This is not news, of course. The article only lists top 5 and bottom 5, so no word on where Walgreens rests, other than "below the Orioles." Losers. Stats suggest \'Bad Ubaldo\' might also be \'Bad Luck Ubaldo\' in 2016 - BaltimoreBaseball.comIf you\'re out there wanting to argue that a big problem Ubaldo Jimenez has faced in the 2016 season is bad luck, do yourself a favor and stop.    11U Clarksville Orioles Win World Series | ClarksvilleNow.comAs you may know, it is the ongoing editorial position of this blog to celebrate the successes of all Orioles teams, everywhere, in any sport, whenever they come to our attention. Here, some young Orioles from Clarksville, TN are winners. Congratulations to them! And finally, a piece of advice to people of all ages: Ex-Cardinals executive Christopher Correa gets 46-month sentence for hacking Astros - Houston ChronicleDon\'t commit federal crimes. Don\'t commit other crimes either. Birthdays and anniversaries On this day in 1994, the Orioles were going to play the Mariners, but tiles fell from the ceiling two hours before first pitch and the game was postponed indefinitely due to the risk of further damage. Due to the strike later that season, the game never did get made up. There are two former Orioles with birthdays today. They are: David Segui, who... well, you know. And also 1956-59 second baseman Billy Gardner, who turns 89 years old today. Happy birthday, Mr. Gardner!    Is today your birthday? Happy birthday! Along with those former Orioles, your birthday buddies for today include: inventor of pistols Samuel Colt (1814), notorious accused (but not convicted) maybe-axe-murderer Lizzie Borden (1860), microwave oven inventor Percy Spencer (1894),\xc2\xa0Lynyrd Skynyrd guitarist Allen Collins (1952),\xc2\xa0boxer and Mayor of Kiev Vitaly Klitschko (1971), the current First Minister of Scotland, Nicola Sturgeon (1971), and actor Benedict Cumberbatch (1976). On this day in history... In 711, the Umayyad army of Tariq bin Ziyad defeated the reigning Visigoths in the Battle of Guadalete. I mention this because of all the sentences I ever read in high school Spanish, I recall this the best: "Los moros invadieron a\xc2\xa0Espa\xc3\xb1a en 711." In 1553, the nine day reign of Lady Jane Grey came to an end as "Bloody" Mary I gained support for the English throne instead. In 1903, Maurice Garin was the winner of the first edition of the Tour de France. Defending champion Chris Froome leads the current running of the tour - the 103rd in its existence - by one minute and 47 seconds with four decisive stages in the Alps still to come. In 1963, test pilot Joe Walker flew a North American X-15 to a then-record altitude of 347,800 feet. Because he exceeded 100 kilometers in altitude, this flight is considered a human spaceflight.    ** And that\'s the way it is in Birdland on July 19 - or at least, until something happens later. Have a safe Tuesday. Go Orioles!  ', 'www.camdenchat.com'), ('Orioles injury updates: Kim to DL, Wieters day-to-day ...', ' The Orioles have a few players battling injury problems right now and the news has not turned out for the best for all of them. With Hyun Soo Kim\xe2\x80\x99s name absent from the Tuesday lineup card, it seems clear that he is headed for the disabled list due to his hamstring injury.    That puts the Orioles in a bit of a bind, though of course good teams are going to have to overcome difficulties like this. They will also be without Chris Davis in the starting lineup for a second consecutive game. Davis, who has been battling a virus, wasn\xe2\x80\x99t even in the stadium for last night\xe2\x80\x99s game. He is, at least, well enough that he\xe2\x80\x99s in the clubhouse on Tuesday. To replace Kim on the roster, the Orioles have gone outside of the 40-man roster to bring up Julio Borbon from Bowie. Someone you probably don\xe2\x80\x99t care much about seems to be headed to the great DFA in the sky before game time tonight. UPDATE: The roster move is now official and Henry Urrutia has been designated for assignment. The only surprising thing about that is that it took this long for them to do it. Urrutia had been demoted from Norfolk to Bowie earlier this year and when you are his age and headed the wrong direction, that\xe2\x80\x99s not a great sign. (end update)    Borbon, 30, is a veteran of four MLB seasons who has been kicking around the minors since his last big league action in 2013. Over his MLB career, he has batted .272/.318/.347 in 863 plate appearances to date.    The question of why they would call up Borbon from Bowie rather than one of the Norfolk outfielders is likely answered by none of the Norfolk outfielders really forcing their way into the picture. Borbon, a lefty like Kim, has batted .289/.353/.373 for Bowie this year. That\xe2\x80\x99s not all that great either, but it\xe2\x80\x99s enough, apparently. Baltimore Baseball\xe2\x80\x99s Dan Connolly tweeted that Borbon is \xe2\x80\x9ca favorite of Showalter\xe2\x80\x99s for his outfield defense and speed.\xe2\x80\x9d Maybe he\xe2\x80\x99s actually even good at one or both of those things.    Oh, and on the subject of injuries, Matt Wieters is day-to-day after being hit by a pitch in the foot in Monday\xe2\x80\x99s game. The X-rays came back clean but Wieters is also absent from tonight\xe2\x80\x99s starting lineup. Which gets us this starting nine for Vance Worley\xe2\x80\x99s third start as an Oriole:  Adam Jones - CF Joey Rickard - LF Manny Machado - 3B Mark Trumbo - RF Jonathan Schoop - 2B Pedro Alvarez - DH J.J. Hardy - SS Caleb Joseph - C Ryan Flaherty - 1B  That hardly looks like the lineup of a first place team, but actually, no matter what happens in tonight\xe2\x80\x99s game, the Orioles will end the night in first place. Get well soon, all you ailing Orioles. They need you.  ', 'www.camdenchat.com')]

Continue reading the main story        Advertisement  Continue reading the main story      The win, the Yankees\xe2\x80\x99 third in a row, pushed them over .500 for the first time since June 25 and drew them six and a half games behind the first-place Orioles in the American League East.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  With two more games left here against the Orioles, the victory also gave a boost to the players\xe2\x80\x99 hopes of convincing management that they are viable playoff contenders so that the Yankees do not trade Carlos Beltran, Aroldis Chapman or other veterans for prospects as the Aug. 1 nonwaiver trade deadline nears.\xe2\x80\x9cThe feeling in this clubhouse is really good right now,\xe2\x80\x9d Swarzak said. \xe2\x80\x9cNobody in this room believes we can\xe2\x80\x99t do it.\xe2\x80\x9d Photo       Nathan Eovaldi, who had recently been in the bullpen, started and held the Orioles to one run in five and a third innings. Trumbo, who has 28 home runs, hit the next pitch high into foul territory down the right-field line. ', 'baltimore.cbslocal.com'), ('Orioles Prospects: A glance at several unknown superstars ...', ' Much has been made about the talent drought in the current state of the Orioles system, and rightfully so. As we sit in the middle of the 2016 season, the lack of top prospects within the Birds organization is more than evident.     It dominates the O\xe2\x80\x99s minor-league storylines and tends to blind views of favorable storylines that pop up every night.  Is the farm system in Baltimore as rich as its ever been? Hardly. But at the end of the day, that simple fact sets up \xe2\x80\x9cdiamond in the rough\xe2\x80\x9d situations throughout the organization - opportunities for young unknowns to burst onto the scene.  And thus far in 2016, plenty of firepower has emerged for at-least a second look.     Aderlin Rodriguez - Frederick When the Mets released Rodriguez at the end of last season, they were likely fairly convinced that the end of his road would be near. From 2012-2014, he was a middle-of-the-pack hitter with power potential and errors aplenty at the corner infield slots. Bottom line, he had appeared to be maxed out.     But don\xe2\x80\x99t tell that to the 2016 version of Aderlin Rodriguez. Whatever he\xe2\x80\x99s done since entering the Orioles organization, it\xe2\x80\x99s been working. Over 89 games with Frederick, Rodriguez is hitting .314 with a .911 OPS.  He\xe2\x80\x99s combined for 41 extra-base hits, including 18 doubles and 17 round-trippers. His strikeout rate is slightly high at 23-percent, but in the grand totality of his game, that\xe2\x80\x99s not a terrible concern.     He\xe2\x80\x99s primarily locking down first base for Frederick, but he\xe2\x80\x99s played 90 innings at the hot corner where he has plenty of experience from his time with the Mets.  And while the makeup of the Orioles system doesn\xe2\x80\x99t exactly bode well for his future with the Orioles, certainly don\xe2\x80\x99t count the 24-year-old out of future trade discussions.  Cole Billingsley - Aberdeen It\xe2\x80\x99s a bit odd to talk about a successful outfielder in the Orioles system, isn\xe2\x80\x99t it? Luckily, Billingsley is proving that trends are meant to be broken ... well, at-least through the first 73 at-bats of his first steps in pro ball.     The former South Alabama standout is crushing opposing pitching this season, starting with a .329/.417/.521 trio. Drafted in the 16th round last month, the 22-year-old Ironbird is already finding a way to make it work in the pros.  Sure, it\xe2\x80\x99s early and it\xe2\x80\x99s short-season single A baseball, but why not celebrate a non-catcher/first baseman doing big things at the dish in the system?  What\xe2\x80\x99s encouraging about Billingsley is the sheer potential that could lie ahead. He hit .302 in 2013 before sitting out his entire sophomore season as a medical redshirt. In 2015, he exploded with a .345 average, .437 OBP and 30 stolen bases (which he does have three of in his first 20 games in Aberdeen).  If he follows the path he\xe2\x80\x99s been sprinting since graduating high-school, the former Team USA 16U star might just find his way onto 2017\xe2\x80\x99s top minor-league prospect watch list.  Yermin Mercedes - Delmarva Mercedes is a catcher, which might put him in a difficult position to climb up the ladder moving forward. However, his 2016 numbers are simply too impressive to ignore   - perhaps for other teams around the league.     After spending 2011-2013 in the Dominican Summer League, Mercedes emerged onto the scene last season with a very respectable year in Delmarva. He hit .272 with eight home runs in 64 games, working a total .456 slugging percentage. Not bad, but not nearly close to the totals he\xe2\x80\x99s collected this campaign.  Through 82 games, Mercedes is absolutely crushing the baseball with a .352 average and .558 slugging percentage. He\xe2\x80\x99s getting on base 40 percent of the time as a staple of the middle of Delmarva\xe2\x80\x99s lineup, hitting 11 home runs with 53 RBI in the process.  His .390 average against left-handers is just one more reason why he\xe2\x80\x99s become the clear contender for Orioles minor-leaguer of the year. And depending on what he looks like behind the dish, Mercedes could eventually emerge as a premier prize in a future trade situation.  Next Wednesday, we\xe2\x80\x99ll go over three surprise arms toeing the rubber in the 2016 Orioles system.   ', 'www.camdenchat.com'), ('Yankees\\u2019 Best Move?                     });                 });             }          } })();  For the Yankees to win at the trading deadline, they need another team to panic. In Aroldis Chapman, they have precisely the kind of player to make rival executives lose their sense of reason.It has happened before, and with a closer nowhere near the caliber of Chapman, who conveniently hit 105 miles an hour on the radar gun against Baltimore on Monday. He was not needed Tuesday as the Yankees beat the Orioles, 7-1.\xe2\x80\x9cWe just need to keep playing good baseball,\xe2\x80\x9d catcher Brian McCann said. \xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99re playing a lot of teams in our division, and we knew coming back from the All-Star break this is a huge homestand for us.\xe2\x80\x9dAt 47-46, the Yankees have at least modest hope of squeezing into contention and keeping their roster intact. But selling can have its advantages, too. Just ask Dan Duquette, the Orioles\xe2\x80\x99 executive vice president for baseball operations, who traded his closer in 1997 for pillars of a future championship team.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Working for the Boston Red Sox then, Duquette acquired Derek Lowe and Jason Varitek from Seattle for Heathcliff Slocumb, fleecing a Mariners team trying desperately to win with Ken Griffey Jr., Randy Johnson and Alex Rodriguez in their primes. A confluence of factors made the deal happen, and while the Yankees cannot count on such good luck now, they should wait as long as they can, hoping that a team will decide it simply cannot live without Chapman or Andrew Miller. Continue reading the main story        Advertisement  Continue reading the main story      For now, of course, the Yankees are still trying to define themselves. They were .500 before the All-Star break and then lost two before winning three in a row. On Wednesday they will try to lift their record to two games above .500 for the first time since April 12. Photo       At the trading deadline in 1997, Seattle gave up Derek Lowe and Jason Varitek to get Heathcliff Slocumb, above, from Boston.  Credit             Otto Greule Jr/Getty Images           \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s been frustrating this year,\xe2\x80\x9d Manager Joe Girardi said before the game, \xe2\x80\x9cbecause we\xe2\x80\x99ve been here so many times and we haven\xe2\x80\x99t been able to break through, for a number of different reasons. Sometimes it\xe2\x80\x99s been offense; sometimes it\xe2\x80\x99s been pitching. It hasn\xe2\x80\x99t been just one reason. But it\xe2\x80\x99s been frustrating because I feel like if we can get over that mark, we can build on it.\xe2\x80\x9dBarring a sudden surge in coming games against the contenders Baltimore, San Francisco and Houston \xe2\x80\x94 and the also-ran Tampa Bay Rays \xe2\x80\x94 the Yankees may find themselves in roughly the same spot in the hours before the 4 p.m. nonwaiver trading deadline on Aug. 1. It is not an enviable position.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s kind of hard when you\xe2\x80\x99re neither fish nor fowl, you haven\xe2\x80\x99t declared, you\xe2\x80\x99re in the middle,\xe2\x80\x9d Duquette said. \xe2\x80\x9cYou don\xe2\x80\x99t know whether to unload or add players. But it was easy for us because we were out of the race. It was pretty clear we weren\xe2\x80\x99t going to be in contention the rest of the way.\xe2\x80\x9d  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  On the morning of July 30, 1997, the Red Sox were 50-56 and trailing by 11 games for a playoff spot. The Mariners were in first place in the American League West and happened to be playing at Fenway Park, where they took a 7-2 lead into the bottom of the eighth inning.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  A procession of overmatched relievers \xe2\x80\x94 Bobby Ayala, Bob Wells, a fading Norm Charlton and Edwin Hurtado \xe2\x80\x94 turned the game into a ghastly 8-7 loss that exposed a chronic Mariners weakness. Right in the middle of it, Slocumb pitched a scoreless ninth inning for the Red Sox.\xe2\x80\x9cHe threw the ball great, and I think Lou Piniella liked him,\xe2\x80\x9d Duquette said, referring to the Mariners\xe2\x80\x99 manager, who was famously competitive and impatient. \xe2\x80\x9cLou had seen him perform well against his team. Slocumb had a pretty good slurve to go with his fastball, and he\xe2\x80\x99d pitched as well as he could pitch against Seattle.\xe2\x80\x9d  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Generally, though, Slocumb was not pitching well; after blowing the save in Kansas City the next day, his E.R.A. rose to 5.79. But he had saved 63 games in the prior two seasons, and the Mariners were scrambling. Earlier on July 31, they had traded their top prospect, outfielder Jose Cruz Jr., to Toronto for relievers Paul Spoljaric and Mike Timlin. Privacy Policy    \xe2\x80\x9cI called up Woody, and I said, \xe2\x80\x98Does that Spoljaric trade take us off the table?\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d Duquette said, referring to Woody Woodward, the Mariners\xe2\x80\x99 top baseball executive. \xe2\x80\x9cHe said, \xe2\x80\x98Not necessarily.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Duquette wanted Varitek, a catcher who had been drafted in the first round in 1993 and 1994 but did not sign until April 1995. The delay had somewhat diminished Varitek\xe2\x80\x99s market value, and the Mariners had another young catcher, Dan Wilson, on their roster. Varitek was available, and when Duquette said he also wanted a pitcher, Woodward suggested Lowe.Two of Duquette\xe2\x80\x99s scouts, Eddie Haas and Gary Rajsich, liked Lowe\xe2\x80\x99s athleticism and approved the idea, despite Lowe\xe2\x80\x99s poor showing with the Mariners that season: 2-4 with a 6.96 E.R.A.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  The sides struck a deal, and the Mariners held on to first place, with Slocumb on the mound when they clinched the division title. But they fell in the first playoff round, and seven years later, Lowe won the clinching game of the World Series for Boston with Varitek behind the plate. Varitek was back there again in 2007 when the Red Sox won another title.Duquette was long gone by then, dismissed after an ownership change in 2002. But he attended the ceremony when the Red Sox put Varitek in their Hall of Fame.  \xe2\x80\x9cThat was a terrific deal for the Red Sox,\xe2\x80\x9d Duquette said, understatedly. \xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99d like to make a deal like that every year, but they don\xe2\x80\x99t always come along.\xe2\x80\x9d  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Yet sometimes they do, and the Yankees would be wise to use their considerable leverage. Several division leaders \xe2\x80\x94 the Giants, the Chicago Cubs, the Cleveland Indians and the Texas Rangers \xe2\x80\x94 have an obvious need for a closer like Chapman or Miller. If they endure a well-timed bullpen blowup, they just might make an impulsive deal for a quick fix, no matter the cost. [('Orioles snap losing streak by beating Yankees, 4-1 ...', ' The Orioles offense may go through slumps, as all teams do, but you can\xe2\x80\x99t keep them down forever. After sleepwalking through the first three games against the Yankees, after deploying B and C team lineups due to sickness in the clubhouse and injuries to key players, the O\xe2\x80\x99s bats finally got going, at least a little bit, on Thursday afternoon, beating the Yankees, 4-1. Although the O\xe2\x80\x99s did have Manny Machado and Chris Davis back from battling the mystery illness, they were still without Matt Wieters and Adam Jones due to assorted injuries. Fortunately, their best starting pitcher, Chris Tillman, was on the mound. Tillman pitched well for seven innings, the Orioles offense got a few clutch hits, then the All-Star duo of Brad Brach and Zach Britton took over to close things out. That might not be how they drew it up back in March, but it\xe2\x80\x99s about as good as a game can go for the O\xe2\x80\x99s as things stand right now. Scoring in the first inning can be done The Orioles scored not only one, but two runs in the first inning. Yes, it can be done! Not that they got any help in getting these runs across from today\xe2\x80\x99s leadoff hitter, Nolan Reimold, who\xe2\x80\x99s batting .224 since the beginning of May. It still wasn\xe2\x80\x99t the A-list lineup even with Machado and Davis back.    There are plenty of other good hitters to go around, like the best friend tandem of Machado and Jonathan Schoop. It was Schoop who got the first inning rally started with a single, moving up to third when his buddy added another single.    With how this road trip had gone to date, getting a runner in scoring position was, in a facetious yet totally real way, putting the Orioles right where Yankees starter, and birthday boy, CC Sabathia wanted them to be. The ice cold Mark Trumbo popped out for the second out. Trumbo hasn\xe2\x80\x99t driven in a run since the All-Star break. But Sabathia walked Davis to load the bases for J.J. Hardy, and Hardy delivered a hard smash that Yankees shortstop Didi Gregorius couldn\xe2\x80\x99t handle.    Two runs scored when the ball caromed into shallow left field and the Orioles had their first clutch hit of the decade. The preceding sentence has not been fact-checked. Staked to this 2-0 lead, Tillman proceeded to walk the first batter he saw in the bottom half of the inning. A base hit put two men on base with none out. Here we go again. But no, actually, Tillman induced a double play ground ball from the Night\xe2\x80\x99s King, Carlos Beltran, defusing the worst of the tension. The second inning saw another spot of trouble for Tillman after Gregorius led off with a double. That run eventually scored on a Starlin Castro single, cutting the Orioles lead to 2-1. Another double play snuffed out that possible rally.    Pitchers entering a groove That was only the second inning and as it worked out, the Yankees did not get another runner in scoring position for the remainder of the game. Tillman entered cruise control mode. Four of the next five innings, the Yankees went 1-2-3 against Tillman. It\xe2\x80\x99s absolutely what the team needs from their best starting pitcher in order to break a losing streak at four games. The term "stopper" is one often thrown around hopefully rather than reflecting reality, but that\xe2\x80\x99s what Tillman was today. They needed it. Sabathia got into a groove, too, after allowing the two runs in the first inning. He retired 18 out of the next 20 Orioles he faced after the Hardy single. That took him all the way into the seventh inning where, with the bottom of the Orioles lineup coming up, he seemed set to keep cruising. That\xe2\x80\x99s not how it worked out. Caleb Joseph, of all people, started off a rally with a single. Joseph has hardly hit a lick lately but he had two hits in this game, despite it being a day game after a night game. Joseph caught both! So that actually can be done. Crazy. Anyway, newly-minted Oriole Julio Borbon got another base hit behind Joseph, getting another actual rally going for the top of the lineup. Reimold struck out. Don\xe2\x80\x99t worry though, because here\xe2\x80\x99s Schoop to save the day! Schoop delivered a clutch double for two crucial insurance runs, putting the Orioles up 4-1.    With Tillman rocking and rolling, that was more than enough. Tillman went on to finish the seventh. His line for the day was beautiful: One run on four hits and two walks, with seven strikeouts, in seven innings. Tillman threw 102 pitches on the day and earned a well-deserved 14th win on the season. Hopes remain for the first O\xe2\x80\x99s 20-game winner since Mike Boddicker in 1984. Tillman\xe2\x80\x99s got time. He\xe2\x80\x99s probably got 11-12 starts remaining and six more wins to get. Oh, and his ERA is now 3.18, good for eighth best among AL starters. Brach and Britton ended the game with little drama, combining for only one man reaching base in the two innings they pitched. The combined ERA for this tandem is now 1.52. That is also good. Britton remains perfect on save opportunities this season: 30 out of 30. The latest road trip from hell is over with. The Orioles return to Baltimore to kick off a three game series against a fellow contending team, the Indians. They\xe2\x80\x99ve really wasted an opportunity in this series. The Red Sox, who\xe2\x80\x99ve now passed the O\xe2\x80\x99s, were playing a fellow first place team in the Giants and still managed to gain ground. Boston now gets to play the pathetic Twins while the O\xe2\x80\x99s face a first place team.    Nothing they can do about it now except for come home, get well, and get back to winning games. In an interesting twist, the 7:05 series opener will feature two starting pitchers picked back-to-back in the 2011 draft: #3 and #4 overall picks Trevor Bauer and Dylan Bundy.                     });                 });             }          } })();  It is hard to know these Yankees at the moment. There was Michael Pineda, pitching out of trouble instead of into it. There was Mark Teixeira, picking up the offense instead of letting it down.Why, there was even the 39-year-old Carlos Beltran, given a respite as the designated hitter, legging out a bunt for a base hit.Suddenly, after more than three months of sporadic, sputtering baseball, these Yankees are playing as if they intend to have a say in the playoff chase after all, winning their fourth consecutive game in their division, a 5-0 victory over the Baltimore Orioles.The victory moved the Yankees two games over .500 for the first time since April 12 and drew them within six games of Boston, which moved past Baltimore into first place in the American League East on Wednesday night. Continue reading the main story        Advertisement  Continue reading the main story      Stalwart starting pitching, a lockdown bullpen, a dose of manufactured runs and a sprinkling of home runs have left the Yankees playing with a degree of confidence they have rarely displayed.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  \xe2\x80\x9cSwagger,\xe2\x80\x9d said reliever Nick Goody, whose perfect eighth helped the bullpen run its scoreless streak to 28\xe2\x85\x94 innings. \xe2\x80\x9cIt was good to get away for the All-Star break. Everybody\xe2\x80\x99s refreshed, everybody\xe2\x80\x99s recharged, and then the guys that went have obviously been doing it all year. Also, the people that might have been a little uncomfortable in the beginning are getting comfortable. When everybody is playing for each other. It makes it a fun environment.\xe2\x80\x9dWinning is not the only thing that is contagious around Yankee Stadium at the moment. So, too, is a virus in the clubhouse of the Orioles, who have lost the first three games of this series, which concludes Thursday. First baseman Chris Davis has missed each of those losses, and he was joined on the sideline by third baseman Manny Machado and Manager Buck Showalter, who took ill Wednesday. Showalter is expected to return Thursday.Catcher Matt Wieters and reliever Zach Britton were the first to become sick, picking up a bug at the All-Star Game in San Diego. The coaches Wayne Kirby and Dom Chiti have also become sick in recent days.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  The Yankees\xe2\x80\x99 pitching has not helped. Pineda followed Masahiro Tanaka, Ivan Nova and Nathan Eovaldi \xe2\x80\x94 who had each allowed one run in the previous three victories \xe2\x80\x94 and did them one better. It is the first time since 2003 that the Yankees have allowed one run or fewer in four consecutive games. Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  In the fourth, J. J. Hardy\xe2\x80\x99s single to right field loaded the bases \xe2\x80\x94 Adam Jones was held at third in deference to Aaron Hicks\xe2\x80\x99s arm \xe2\x80\x94 with one out. But Pineda struck out Nolan Reimold and Ryan Flaherty with sliders to escape. The usually emotive Pineda exhorted himself, then put his head down and ambled to the dugout.After Mark Trumbo doubled and took third on a fly ball in the sixth, Pineda fanned Hardy \xe2\x80\x94 who was 9 for 17 in his career against him, including two hits Tuesday \xe2\x80\x94 with a 96-mile-per-hour fastball and then Reimold with his 113th and final pitch, a slider. On his way to the dugout, Pineda \xe2\x80\x94 who has so often seemed to find trouble in the most benign circumstances \xe2\x80\x94 got a congratulatory hand slap from Manager Joe Girardi.\xe2\x80\x9cWhen you get outs with runners in scoring position, those are the most crucial outs of a game,\xe2\x80\x9d Girardi said. \xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s usually the difference in a game.\xe2\x80\x9d  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  As encouraging as Pineda\xe2\x80\x99s performance was, the most buoying one might have been by Teixeira, who had missed the previous three games after fouling a ball off his foot. Teixeira hit a solo home run to right in the fourth and drew two walks. The second, with the bases loaded, put the Yankees ahead, 3-0.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Teixeira has looked battered, beaten and broken much of this season. He has been afflicted by a variety of ailments \xe2\x80\x94 his neck, a knee and most recently his foot \xe2\x80\x94 and when he has been healthy, he has not hit. He began Wednesday with a .186 batting average and had endured a career-worst home run drought.\xe2\x80\x9cThis has been brutal,\xe2\x80\x9d said Teixeira, whose eight-year, $180 million contract expires after this season. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve been terrible. The only thing I can do is the last two months try to be healthy and get hot. I live off my hot streaks; I haven\xe2\x80\x99t had one this year.\xe2\x80\x9d  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  If the Yankees do not get one \xe2\x80\x94 from Teixeira or Rodriguez, or another middle-of-the-order bat that might be available between now and the Aug. 1 nonwaiver trade deadline \xe2\x80\x94 they will need to keep playing as they are now.They had productive at-bats, with Beltran and Brett Gardner delivering sacrifice flies. Ronald Torreyes, making an emergency start for third baseman Chase Headley \xe2\x80\x94 who was not at the ballpark for personal reasons \xe2\x80\x94 tripled and scored.And Beltran, who hit a solo homer, his 20th of the season, also dropped down a bunt single against a shift that moved Jacoby Ellsbury to second. Two more walks brought in a run.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  \xe2\x80\x9cWe know if we play our \xe2\x80\x98A\xe2\x80\x99 game, we can beat good teams,\xe2\x80\x9d Teixeira said. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd we\xe2\x80\x99re going to have to if we want to stay in this thing.\xe2\x80\x9d  A version of this article appears in print on July 21, 2016, on Page B13 of the New York edition with the headline: Yanks Get Unexpected Help to Win Fourth in Row.                     });                 });             }          } })();  Baseball players engage in all sorts of rituals to maintain their gloves, pounding the hardened spots with customized tools or using a variety of oils to soften them. Although it seems easy, closing a glove around a baseball is sometimes harder than it looks.Case in point: Thursday afternoon\xe2\x80\x99s game at Yankee Stadium. On three occasions, Yankees infielders failed to secure a ball, and each time, the defensive miscue led to a run. As a result, the Yankees were unable to complete a four-game sweep of the Baltimore Orioles, falling by 4-1.C. C. Sabathia pitched well on his 36th birthday, but he was foiled by soft base hits. Sabathia tossed six and two-thirds innings, allowing two runs in the first inning and two more in the seventh.\xe2\x80\x9cI thought he gave us a gritty performance today \xe2\x80\x94 it\xe2\x80\x99s unfortunate,\xe2\x80\x9d Manager Joe Girardi said. \xe2\x80\x9cHe didn\xe2\x80\x99t give up a lot of hard-hit balls, and you look up and there\xe2\x80\x99s four runs on the board.\xe2\x80\x9d Continue reading the main story        Advertisement  Continue reading the main story      The Orioles\xe2\x80\x99 initial hit came when Yankees shortstop Didi Gregorius did not cleanly scoop a slow roller off the bat of Jonathon Schoop in the first inning. The Orioles eventually loaded the bases for J. J. Hardy, who hit a sharp line drive that deflected off the top of Gregorius\xe2\x80\x99s mitt and fell into left field, bringing home two runs.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Sabathia allowed only one hit over his next five innings before allowing back-to-back one-out singles in the seventh. That brought up Schoop again, and he doubled to right, easily scoring Caleb Joseph. Right fielder Carlos Beltran fired the ball to Mark Teixeira at first base as Julio Borbon rounded third, but Teixeira dropped the throw, and Borbon scored.Despite having his bullpen ready, Girardi chose to stay with Sabathia in the seventh. After the game, Girardi repeatedly defended his decision, pointing to Sabathia\xe2\x80\x99s previous success against Schoop, who was 3 for 13 until that point against him.\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re probably extremely frustrated, because when you\xe2\x80\x99re not giving up hard contact, you\xe2\x80\x99re making good pitches, and it\xe2\x80\x99s frustrating for him and for us that they\xe2\x80\x99re turning into base hits,\xe2\x80\x9d Girardi said, adding about the Schoop at-bat, \xe2\x80\x9cYou look at the base hit, it wasn\xe2\x80\x99t hit hard, it was just extremely well placed.\xe2\x80\x9d Sign Up for the Sports Newsletter Get the big sports news, highlights and analysis from Times journalists, with distinctive takes on games and some behind-the-scenes surprises, delivered to your inbox every week. Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Tillman allowed one run on four hits over seven innings, and the relievers who followed him allowed only one other hit. Over all, the Yankees sluggers Beltran, Brian McCann, Teixeira and Alex Rodriguez, who was moved down to seventh in the order, were hitless in a combined 14 at-bats.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  \xe2\x80\x9cTillman was almost unhittable,\xe2\x80\x9d Teixeira said.The Orioles\xe2\x80\x99 victory brought a bit of calm after a negative start to the series. In addition to dropping the first three games against the Yankees, the Orioles fell out of first place in the American League East, passed by the Boston Red Sox. On Wednesday, Manager Buck Showalter, first baseman Chris Davis and third baseman Manny Machado were absent from the game because of flulike symptoms that have spread through the Orioles\xe2\x80\x99 clubhouse.The bug reportedly originated at the All-Star Game in San Diego last week, infecting catcher Matt Wieters and reliever Zach Britton. Despite his sparkling record, Tillman was not selected as an All-Star, but he is probably happy to be in good health.Showalter did not hold his customary pregame news conference with reporters on Thursday, but he was in the dugout to manage the game.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Orioles players said they had been washing their hands more thoroughly and using hand sanitizer to prevent the illness from spreading further.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Before Thursday\xe2\x80\x99s loss, the Yankees showed signs of mounting a charge up the standings after entering the series eight and a half games out of first place in the A.L. East. They shaved their deficit slightly, although three teams remain ahead of them in the division standings.\xe2\x80\x9cI think you have to look at it as you took three of four from a good Baltimore team, and you have to move on,\xe2\x80\x9d Girardi said.INSIDE PITCHThe Yankees optioned NICK GOODY to Class AAA Scranton/Wilkes-Barre and recalled CHAD GREEN, who pitched two and a third scoreless innings in relief Thursday. \xe2\x80\xa6 CHASE HEADLEY pinch-hit in the eighth inning after missing Wednesday\xe2\x80\x99s game for personal reasons. Headley said after the game that his son, Colt, 4, had an operation over the All-Star break last week and had recently had complications. On Wednesday, Headley took his son back to the hospital for another procedure, and Headley said Thursday that Colt was \xe2\x80\x9cdoing a lot better.\xe2\x80\x9d  A version of this article appears in print on July 22, 2016, on Page B11 of the New York edition with the headline: Little Things Hurt Yankees, Who Can\xe2\x80\x99t Complete Sweep of Orioles.
